Apply residual debiasing for a single SDA time step

Source: R/debias_step.R
sda_apply_debias_step.Rd

Apply residual debiasing for a single SDA time step

Usage

sda_apply_debias_step(
  t,
  obs.t,
  X,
  raw_prev,
  raw_mean_t,
  site_index,
  col_vars,
  obs.times,
  obs.mean,
  covariates_df,
  py,
  train_buf,
  name_map = debias_name_map,
  drop_incomplete_covariates = TRUE,
  enforce_consistent_obs = TRUE,
  require_obs_at_t_for_predict = FALSE,
  state.interval = state.interval,
  clip_lower_bound = 0.01
)

Arguments

t

Integer current time index (t > 1 required to train from t–1).

obs.t

Character or time label for logging (e.g., ISO date string for `t`).

X

Numeric matrix of the **current** ensemble at time `t` (members × columns).

raw_prev

Numeric vector of the **raw** column mean at `t-1`.

raw_mean_t

Numeric vector of the **raw** column mean at `t`.

site_index

Vector of site ids per column of `X`.

col_vars

Vector of variable names per column of `X` (state-space names).

obs.times

Datetime vector indexed by `t` (length ≥ `t`) for covariate year lookup.

obs.mean

Observation structure (time → site → named numeric vector).

covariates_df

Long data frame with columns `site`, `year`, and feature columns.

py

Python bridge object exposing: - `train_full_model(name, X, y)`, - `predict_residual(name, X)`, - `get_model_weights(name)`, - `has_model(name)` (logical).

train_buf

R environment used to accumulate training rows per variable across steps.

name_map

Optional map from observation names → state names.

drop_incomplete_covariates

Logical; if `TRUE`, drop sites with missing covariates (per year).

enforce_consistent_obs

Logical; if `TRUE`, drop sites inconsistent up to relevant `t_idx`.

require_obs_at_t_for_predict

Logical; if `TRUE`, only predict residuals for columns with

state.interval

Matrix/data.frame of per-variable bounds; either rownames = variable with columns `min`,`max`, or a data frame with a `variable` column plus `min`/`max`. Used to clip post-debias values.

clip_lower_bound

Numeric; minimum floor applied to lower bounds (default 0.01). **observations present at t** (useful for constrained comparisons).

Value

A list with:

X

The **mean-shifted** ensemble matrix at time `t` (same dims as input `X`).

weights_entry

Optional named list of learner weights by variable (if provided by `py`).

weights_df_rows

A tidy data frame of weights emitted this step (time, var, learner, weight).

diag

A list with:

  • `comp`: per-column comparison table (`pre`, `post`, `obs`) for diagnostics.

  • `rmse`: per-variable metrics (RMSE/MAE/bias/R²) **pre vs post**.

rmse_rows

A tidy slice of metrics with the `time` column attached for easy logging.

Details

At time `t`, this function: 1. Builds a training set from **t–1**: residuals `y = obs_prev - raw_prev` and features `[covariates_prev, raw_prev]` for each variable. 2. Trains/updates the Python-side learner (`py$train_full_model`). 3. Predicts residuals at **t** using `[covariates_t, raw_mean_t]`. 4. Mean-shifts the ensemble `X` by adding predicted residuals to `raw_mean_t`. 5. Computes per-variable metrics (RMSE, MAE, bias, R²) pre vs post.

Note

- If covariates are missing (no feature columns) for either `t-1` or `t`, the function returns `X` unchanged and emits NA metrics (shape-preserving behavior). - Predicted residuals that are non-finite are coerced to 0 to avoid contaminating `X`. - The **mean-shift** keeps the ensemble spread intact: we subtract the raw mean and add the corrected mean (`raw_mean_t + predicted_residual`).
